title: Mike Ashley 'meets with Mexican businessmen' over Newcastle takeover
text:

Mike Ashley has reportedly met with two Mexican businessmen to discuss proposals to sell Newcastle United.

The Newcastle owner has been looking for investors to take over the club, but has so far failed to attract any serious offers.

Ashley held a meeting in London last week, according to the Athletic , but the talks are believed to have come to nothing.

He is said to have come across as "rude" and it now seems the negotiations will not progress further.

The Mexicans had harboured an interest in buying Newcastle since watching the film Goal! in which fictional footballer Santiago Munez - of Mexico - earns a trial at the club and goes on to become a professional.

(Image: Getty Images)

Newcastle have already had interest from Mexican club owners back in May, but it is not known whether these are the same party.

The Orlegi Group, who own Mexican club Santos Laguna and are spearheaded by Alejandro Iraragorri, were considering Newcastle as a potential investment.

Ashley is demanding £300 million for the club, but has yet to receive a concrete offer.

Ex-Man Utd and Chelsea chief executive was involved with a consortium interested in acquiring Newcastle, but have since gone cold.

(Image: Getty Images)

Newcastle have been struggling in the league this season, and fell to their latest defeat against Chelsea on Saturday.

The now sit inside the relegation zone with just two wins from nine matches.

Recent figures have also shown that the club's fans have been turned off of going to watch at St James' Park, with average attendances down almost 5,000 from last season.

The report from worldfootball.net showed that 46,577 people have been to home matches this season, compared with 51,121 in the previous campaign.

It means that St James’ Park has only been 89% full on average this season.

No other Premier League club is operating at such a low percentage of capacity.
description: The club previously attracted interest from a consortium led by ex-Chelsea chief Peter Kenyon but are yet to receive any bids
